abstract.p: Family Fare column list some activities of interest to families in New York; photo (S)

block.p: FOR CHILDREN

Theater ''ALICE IN WONDERLAND,'' a musical-theater production by the American Family Theater, featuring all the familiar characters, Sunday at 1:30 p.m. at the TriBeCa Performing Arts Center, 199 Chambers Street. Tickets: $13; $8 for children. Reservations: (212) 346-8510.
FOR CHILDREN

Theater ''ALICE IN WONDERLAND,'' a musical-theater production by the American Family Theater, featuring all the familiar characters, Sunday at 1:30 p.m. at the TriBeCa Performing Arts Center, 199 Chambers Street. Tickets: $13; $8 for children. Reservations: (212) 346-8510.

''CHARLOTTE'S WEB,'' E. B. White's classic tale of Wilbur the pig and Charlotte the spider, who assures her friend Wilbur that she will save him from the butcher, adapted by Joseph Robinette. Presented by the Pied Piper Children's Theater, made up of children ages 5 to 14. Tomorrow at 3 and 7 p.m. at Holy Trinity Episcopal Church, 20 Cumming Street, Inwood. Tickets: $16; $3 for children under 18. Information: (212) 567-2329.

''KINGDOM OF THE SUN,'' directed by Zac Whinnem, is knights and courtiers, Monty Python style.Josh Cagan's play is also a feminist fairy tale in which the king's female page, Harold, saves him. She longs to be a knight. and much of the fun is seeing how she wins this honor and lives happily ever after, no Prince Charming required. Sundays through May 21 at 2 p.m. Manhattan Theater Source, 177 Macdougal Street, Greenwich Village. Tickets: $7. Reservations: (212) 501-4751.

SINGIN' IN THE RAIN, a production by Downtown Art based on the Hollywood musical about the Roaring 20's, complete with gallons of real water. Adapted and directed by Ryan Gilliam and presented by actors 12 to 19 years old. Through May 28. Fridays and Saturdays at 7:30 p.m. (no performance on May 19); Sundays at 2 p.m. Downtown Art, 64 East Fourth Street, East Village. Tickets: $5; ages 18 and under, $4. Reservations: (212) 505-0835.
Events

BIG APPLE CIRCUS. The circus celebrates the clown in ''Bello and Friends,'' through May 21 at Cunningham Park, Queens. The Big Top is on 196-22 Union Turnpike at Francis Lewis Boulevard in Fresh Meadows. Today at 11 a.m. and 6:30 p.m.; tomorrow and Sunday at 12:30 and 4:30 p.m; Tuesday and Wednesday at 11 a.m.; Thursday at 11 a.m. and 6:30 p.m. Tickets: $12 to $32. Ticketmaster: (212) 307-4100.

CENTRAL PARK CONSERVANCY. Two Mother's Day weekend workshops will go on tomorrow from 1 to 2:30 p.m. for youngsters 6 and older: creating candles, including colors and scents inspired by flowers, then making one to take home, at the Charles A. Dana Discovery Center, 110th Street near Fifth Avenue, (212) 860-1370; learning about the scents and fragrances of Central Park and then making scented sachets with materials supplied, at the Henry Luce Nature Observatory at Belvedere Castle, midpark at 79th Street, (212) 772-0210. Free.

''DR. MIRACLE,'' Georges Bizet's comic opera about an omelet, a 19th-century sitcom, will be presented by St. Luke's Chamber Ensemble on Mother's Day, Sunday at 2 p.m. at the 92nd Street Y, at Lexington Avenue. Specially priced benefit tickets are $50 for children and $75 for adults and include a reception in Weill Art Gallery following the one-hour performance. General audience tickets are $5 each. Reservations: (212) 594-6100, extension 110.

''FAMILY JEWELRY DAY,'' a workshop to make brooches, necklaces and bracelets out of beads and found objects, tomorrow from 10 a.m. to noon for children and an accompanying adult, at the Children's Museum of the Arts, 182 Lafayette Street, SoHo. Registration required. Fee: $20 per family for up to four people. Information: (212) 274-0986.
FLOWERS FOR MOM. Youngsters can learn to make a corsage using fresh flowers, tomorrow at noon at the Queens Botanical Garden, 43-50 Main Street, Flushing. Information: (718) 886-3800. Free.

MOTHER'S DAY GALLERY TOUR, Sunday at 11 a.m. and 1 p.m. at the Museum of Jewish Heritage, 18 First Place, at West Street and Battery Place, Battery Park City, of artifacts and exhibitions that relate to the role of women in Jewish history and ritual. Free with admission: $7; students and the elderly, $5; age 5 and under, free. Information: (212) 509-6130.

''PETER, A SYMPHONIC ZOO, AND YOU!'' The final Carnegie Hall Family Concert of the season features a performance of Prokofiev's ''Peter and the Wolf,'' performed by the Orchestra of St. Luke's, conducted by John Morris Russell, tomorrow at 2 p.m. Preconcert activities available to all ticketholders at 1 p.m. will feature demonstrations of the marimba (in both the Rohatyn Room and the Traveler's Group Cafe) and storytelling by Charlotte Blake Alston (on the main stage). Tickets for the demonstrations will be available in the lobby at 12:30 p.m. For children 7 and older. Tickets: $5. Information and reservations: (212) 247-7800.

RUBBINGS WORKSHOP, tomorrow at 2 p.m., at the Museum of the City of New York, Fifth Avenue at 103rd Street, with Cecily Barth Firestein, a printmaker, author and educator. Materials will be provided and sample rubbings will be on display. Free with suggested admission: $7; the elderly, students and children, $4; families, $12. Information: (212) 534-1672, extension 257.

SIMULATED STAINED GLASS CITYSCAPES. Participants in this workshop will use cellophane and contact paper to create a stained-glass panel in the shape of skyscrapers, Sunday from 1 to 4 p.m. at the Queens Museum of Art, Flushing Meadows-Corona Park, as part of a celebration of the ''Panorama of the City of New York,'' the 9,335-square-foot architectural model of the city. Free with admission: $4; $2 for children and the elderly; free for children under 5. Information: (718) 592-9700. The museum is a 10-minute walk through the park. A trolley runs Fridays through Sundays from noon to 6 p.m., $1 for adults and 50 cents for children. Trolley information: (718) 760-6565.

''STORIES AND ART.'' Campbell Geeslin, the author of ''How Nanita Learned to Make Great Flan,'' about a Mexican girl who has many adventures with a talking parrot, will be the subject of a program tomorrow at 4 p.m. at the Brooklyn Museum of Art, 200 Eastern Parkway, at Prospect Park, in the museum's Hall of the Americas. Free with admission: $4; students and the elderly, $2; under 12, free. Information: (718) 638-5000.

''SURF KIDS: THE TRAV S. D. SHOW,'' presented by the retro-garde performing arts company Mountebanks, is the children's part of the Surf Comedy Festival. The slapstick comedy show, which encourages audiences to be rowdy, includes the Trav S. D. Family, the Rev. Jen Miller, Torkova the Magician, Cowboy Tex, Gilda Konrad and Jessica and her puppets, tomorrow at 3 p.m. at Surf Reality, 172 Allen Street, Lower East Side. Tickets: $5. Information: (212) 673-4182.

YOUNG CHOREOGRAPHERS PROJECT, tonight and tomorrow night at 8 at the Brooklyn Arts Exchange, 421 Fifth Avenue, at the corner of Eighth Street, Park Slope, gives teenage choreographers a chance to create new works performed by professional dancers. The performance features work by Ursula Borowa, Miriam Levin and Sarah Wong, students at the Brooklyn Arts Exchange, under the direction of Andrew Jannetti. Admission: $8; $5 for children and low-income. Information: (718) 832-0018.

''WILLIAM WEGMAN: TV LUNCH.'' Audiences will meet the photographer-video maker William Wegman and his canine collaborators Battina and Chip over video screenings and a light meal, tomorrow at 1 p.m. at the Kitchen, 512 West 19th Street, Chelsea. Tickets: $10. Information: (212) 255-5793.

''METROPOLITAN LIFE FAMILY DAY,'' tomorrow at the Museum for African Art, 593 Broadway, near Houston Street, SoHo. At 1 p.m. an African dance class in traditional West African movement. For ages 5 and older; the class is limited to 30. At 3 p.m., a performance by the Aminata Gueye Dance Company performing traditional dance from Senegal. Free with museum admission: $5; $2.50 for students, children and the elderly; free on Sundays. Information: (212) 966-1313.

''MOTHER'S DAY CELEBRATION/A MOM MARATHON,'' Sunday from noon to 5 p.m. at the Staten Island Children's Museum, Snug Harbor Cultural Center, 1000 Richmond Terrace, Livingston. Programs include tea and pastries in Portia's Playhouse (noon to 2 p.m.), a performance of ''Little Red Riding Hood'' by Liz Joyce and her puppets (1:30 and 2:30 p.m.), an introduction to animals from Africa in the ''Bugs and Other Insects'' exhibition hall (2 to 2:30 and 2:45 and 3:15 p.m.) and a picture-frame workshop in which youngsters get photographed with their mothers (1 to 4 p.m.). The programs are free with admission except for the picture frame workshop, which is $2 plus museum admission: $4; free for children under 2 and members. Information: (718) 273-2060.
Exhibitions

''CAN YOU TELL ME HOW TO GET TO SESAME STREET?'' Most children know exactly how to get there: turn on the television set at the right time. An alternative route leads to the Brooklyn Children's Museum, 145 Brooklyn Avenue, at St. Mark's Avenue, Crown Heights. This is where an interactive traveling exhibition (on view through Sept. 3) recreates the set of this PBS series, including the famous front stoop next to Oscar's garbage can. Tomorrow, Sonia Manzano, who plays Maria on the series, will lead a half-hour bilingual ''Sesame Street'' sing-along at 11:30 a.m. and 1 p.m. as part of a Mother's Day celebration. (Seating is first come first served.) In the exhibition youngsters can also become ''Sesame Street Stars''; they can bring a blank videotape and leave with their own movie. Spring hours: Wednesdays through Fridays, 2 to 5 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. Free, with suggested admission: $4.
